details.name: abstract
details.label: Abstract / Summary
values: Client discusses difficulties at work with their supervisor, mentor, and work responsibilities.

details.name: psychotherapy_collection
details.label: Psychotherapy Collection
values: Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy Collection by Anonymous Male Therapist

meta.title: Client "Ju", Session April 08, 2014: Client discusses difficulties at work with their supervisor, mentor, and work responsibilities.
meta.fullTitle: Client "Ju", Session April 08, 2014: Client discusses difficulties at work with their supervisor, mentor, and work responsibilities.

content.html:
TRANSCRIPT OF AUDIO FILE:

BEGIN TRANSCRIPT:

CLIENT: Well, I’m really ouch-y because (ph) I broke into my apartment this morning. (crosstalk at 00:00:45)

THERAPIST: You’re really ouch-y?

CLIENT: Yeah. I crawled through a window, basically doing a handstand to get back into my apartment.

THERAPIST: Why?

CLIENT: Because I left my wallet and keys inside.

THERAPIST: Wow.

CLIENT: In retrospect –

THERAPIST: Kind of Jackie Chan, right there.

CLIENT: Yeah. It was. In retrospect, I really should’ve just called my landlord. But I had just called him the day before. And I don’t know. I wasn’t thinking very (chuckles) well (ph). Yeah. It was a crazy, Jackie Chan move. And no one called the police, so . . .

THERAPIST: Well, that part’s good.

CLIENT: Yeah. (chuckles)

THERAPIST: (chuckles)

CLIENT: Yeah. But I’m definitely—about an hour—when I first did it, I was like, “Oh, I’m fine.” And an hour later, I’m old.

THERAPIST: (chuckles)

CLIENT: (chuckles) I should not have done that. So, super-frustratingly, I found out last week that the paperwork from Dr. Gerrard for me to get FMLA disappeared into the ether.

THERAPIST: Oh, no.

CLIENT: And it’d been needed (ph) for about a month. I just assumed she sent the fax, the paperwork directly to the –

THERAPIST: Sorry. This is FMLA from when?

CLIENT: For now-ish.

THERAPIST: (crosstalk at 00:02:13)

CLIENT: (inaudible at 00:02:14) started in early—mid-February. For (sighs) needing some time off to deal with ongoing medication change problems.

THERAPIST: Had you told me? I didn’t even know about it.

CLIENT: I don’t know.

THERAPIST: Maybe I don’t remember. I don’t remember that. Anyway.

CLIENT: And I’ve been really wanting—I need to use FMLA a lot (crosstalk at 00:02:35). And then, I e-mailed, anticipating (ph) they’d be like, “Hey, what’s up?” And they’re just like, “Yeah, you—well, your doctor hasn’t sent anything in.” So, (chuckles) I just saw her last week. And she’s like, “Okay. I don’t know what happened. Here’s the hard copy.” And then, Friday, I was talking to the disability office. And they—well, basically, like, “Oh, so, how much FMLA have you already taken?” I’m like, “But I thought I couldn’t do that until you said so.”

THERAPIST: Wait. Sorry. Couldn’t do?

CLIENT: So, the disability office asked me what—[had already started] (ph) a reduced schedule, had already taken FMLA time.

THERAPIST: (crosstalk at 00:03:19) I get it. Right. And you’re like, “What?”

CLIENT: Yeah.

THERAPIST: (chuckles)

CLIENT: It’s a complete mess. If I had known that, it would’ve been a lot happier. So, I ended up going home in a really cranky rage fit, because I was just really frustrated. I just want to not be crazy at work like this.

And then, yesterday—yeah. I’m at work, doing whatever. And I got these couple e-mails from various senior managers about (sighs)—it’s one of those things where they—I got tagged in mid-e-mail stream. Some people have (ph) already been talking about something. And then, someone was like, “Oh, we should CC some more people.” And it’s some new technology that someone’s using at, I think, a dental school that seems really cool. And then, Karl’s like, “Oh, my God. Of course we need this in Aurora and Carlisle immediately.” And then, (inaudible at 00:04:45) is going to be like, “Okay. I’m going to have (inaudible at 00:04:47) in IT make—do whatever to get—so we can get this right.” Someone had suggested a pilot. But Karl was like, “No. We can’t have a pilot. We just have to get it now.”

And I actually don’t understand what the thing is supposed to do. I think I remember thinking, “Yeah, people always want to do this. But they can’t.” I think the actual problem is, is that if you’re not part of FAS, you have to register on the FAS network in Aurora. So, if you’re a consultant, you can’t—your computer can’t—we don’t have a network in our building. Unless you arrange for that in advance. Or if someone is from the law school, they can’t come in our network. I think that’s what people were saying was a problem. That they always want to be able to just use their laptop, but they can’t. I think that’s a networking problem.

I don’t know what the software—I generally don’t even know if it’s software or hardware. (inaudible at 00:06:13) I’m (ph) reading this, I’m just like, “Well, in meetings, people can be on their devices to other things.” And I’m just like, “What’s happening?”

From the description, I get that it’s used for meetings and—so, that more than one person can share information in some way. But I don’t know what. But I do know that it’s not going to be piloted. And that’s it’s coming in.

THERAPIST: It’s just going to roll out.

CLIENT: Yeah. Which was super frustrating and upsetting, because everything basically—I’m like, “What does it do? Do you even know what it does? Is this something that we could solve?” And (inaudible at 00:07:17) like, “What?”

THERAPIST: So, you’re saying the only thing you know about it, basically, is that you’re going to be supporting it?

CLIENT: Yeah. And the suggestion to have a pilot was negged. Someone else was like, “Oh, you can come over to the dental school or whatever to check out our implementation.” And the answer was, “No, no. We should just buy it. And sell it.”

I’m guessing probably because the dental school is not close by. But honestly, all the things (inaudible at 00:07:58) cars. They can just drive. Or take the shuttle. It’s free.

THERAPIST: The dental school’s by the medical school, right?

CLIENT: Yeah. You just take the M2 shuttle.

THERAPIST: (crosstalk at 00:08:06), yeah.

CLIENT: Yeah. For free. Yeah. I mean, it takes a while. But whatever. It’s right there. So, yeah, what I know about it basically is that I get to support it. And that’s about it. And then, maybe a 3D printer in Aurora. Because another one of (inaudible at 00:08:33) libraries, it’s getting one. They’re not, however, currently planning to buy the software that allows you to make your own 3D objects to print.

THERAPIST: (laughs)

CLIENT: (chuckles) That wasn’t part of the plan. Fortunately, one of my coworkers was like, “You know, you have to buy the thing that lets you do it.” So, if (inaudible at 00:09:04) about the unknown. And then, also e-mail from Christy (inaudible at 00:09:12), who’s one of the senior managers, about some interesting workshops at (inaudible at 00:09:19), at a local conference.

And [I’m like] (ph), “These look really interesting.” And then, I realized—and then, I was like, “But I bet I can’t go, because I’m not a professional employee.” And I don’t have professional [development funds] (ph). And Chet says I can’t go to a conference, because I might work (inaudible at 00:09:42) hours in the day.

I read them all in one bunch. And then, I started crying. And again, I couldn’t really stop. I kind of did enough to be—to decide that I was going to go home. And send (ph) an e-mail. And not forget the student worker, who was in the office with me. But that’s about it. (sighs)

And then, today, I found out that there is another another group (ph) department (inaudible at 00:10:38) technology coming into the building that’s going to need to be there at (inaudible at 00:10:43).

THERAPIST: That’s going to what?

CLIENT: It’s going into one of the main rooms that I support. Which I didn’t know about. (sighs)

And combined with that, I met with my labor mentor, Laney, again, on, I don’t know, like Thursday or something. And, well, we had a nice lunch, whatever. It’s getting near the end of the mentorship program, so, she was asking me some questions. And I said that I really feel like the answer is I can’t do anything I want to at Manchester. Her response was, “Weren’t you considering leaving Manchester anyway?” Sort of. I’m planning to move to New Mexico. Not really the same as leaving Manchester, I guess. I mean, my plan isn’t, “I want to leave Manchester.” My plan has been, “I want to move to New Mexico.” And it also felt really dismissive. Like, “Well, I thought you were already going to leave.”

And we talked a little bit. And then, she (chuckles) gave me some printouts of—she’s like, “(inaudible at 00:12:25) here’s some printouts of some articles I saw that I thought might be helpful for you.” And I was like, “You gave me printouts. Okay. That’s funny. [And cool] (ph).”

So, half of them are articles about managing (inaudible at 00:12:44) difficult manager and blah, blah, blah. Which I’d read about. One of the problems that I run into is—I run into with her is that she’s like, “Okay. Well, did you try x, y, and z?” I’m like, “Yes.” And she’s like, “Well, but it doesn’t make any sense that Chet [would completely ignore] (ph) you.” I’m like, “Yes, that’s true.” And then, she’s like, “Well, but you must not have,” I’m like, “I’m really did try.”

THERAPIST: But actually, I did. Yeah.

CLIENT: And this weird, “But it’s not possible that he could be”—or that people—I get that it doesn’t make any sense. And it’s not helpful. And stupid. And (inaudible at 00:13:43). But it’s still happening.

So, that was frustrating. And then, she gave me three articles that basically—dress for success. One that like, “You should dress for the job that you want.” Blah, blah, blah. And (sighs) I know she meant well.

THERAPIST: Kind of insulting. Yeah (ph).

CLIENT: It was insulting. In parts, I’m like, “So, it’s true that you often see me in jeans and a tee shirt. I have to crawl around on the regular. I never know when.” And my first response really was, “Can I direct you to the articles that I publish on this topic?” Of (crosstalk at 00:14:40). Yes. (chuckles)

THERAPIST: I’m not really doubting you. I’m just (crosstalk at 00:14:45) –

CLIENT: Yeah. I was like, “I have a published body of work on the topic of how clothing, your (inaudible at 00:14:52) appearance does indeed affect how people react to you.” And that sucks. In particular, an article that was why—respectability politics and why it’s really rare. I may be dressed very casually, but it’s really hard for me to dress crazy sloppy, because, in my head, it’s like my dad and all my relatives being like, “You can’t go out of the house like that because what people will think. You need to dress well so white people don’t think that black people are ignorant,” or whatever ever.

So, I don’t know. For as casual as I get, my jeans are cleaned. They’re not ripped. Shirt’s clean and it’s not ripped. It’s not (inaudible at 00:15:59), whatever.

THERAPIST: Yeah. It’s casual. It’s not messy.

CLIENT: Yeah. And also, it’s not—every (ph) part of me is like, “Where are we going with this?” Because my mentor’s a very put-together, mildly conservative-dressed woman. Very nice. She works at the business school, where you have to look like that. And I’m just like, “I’m not sure this is going to overcome”—if I decided to wear a nice dress and pumps. Or make-up or whatever to work every day. Don’t think that’s really going to help with systemic problems.

I’m perfectly capable of dressing up when I’m supposed to. People are going through. But (sighs) it was I don’t even know.

I actually wasn’t insulted so much by the concept of her thinking, “It’s important for my mentee to dress professionally.” I was more insulted by the idea (chuckles) that I hadn’t thought about it.

THERAPIST: (inaudible at 00:17:38) about it.

CLIENT: Yeah. I was like, “I publish things in books. And a variety of other pieces. And I’m not going to bring that up, probably, because I think (chuckles) it would be—it would come off needlessly hostile.”

THERAPIST: Why?

CLIENT: (sighs) Because, well, it’s just my in-my-head response is basically, “I’d like to refer you to my published body of work.”

THERAPIST: I believe that if you had, it would—it is quite hostile. (chuckles)

CLIENT: (chuckles) So, that is not—so, there’s—I don’t know if it’s hostile, but I am very—I’m pretty sure that she’s not interested in a discussion about (inaudible at 00:18:47) politics. I’m pretty sure that she is deeply into or supportive of respectability. (inaudible at 00:19:00) you have to dress respectively at all times. (inaudible at 00:19:04) that’s how she seems to dress, which is totally fine.

And I guess part of what makes me feel like it’s going to go poorly or may come off hostile is A), I just—I don’t know. I feel like she handing me some really basic articles or concepts. The way she came in with, “Have you thought of wearing pantyhose?” Or I don’t even know. “Have you thought of not wearing jeans?” And I’m like, “Yes. I have. And these (inaudible at 00:19:55) the reasons why I’m not. And this is also some political thoughts I have on this issue. And here’s my (inaudible at 00:20:02) gay, feminist, queer, fat-positive critique I have of the whole subject that you’re getting into.” I think that’s a lot of response to, “Dress for success.”

I think, more generally, I just—when she handed me those articles and after we had lunch, I—what I was thinking was I said I really wanted a mentor who was a woman of color. Or a person of color. I guess what I actually meant was I’d like a mentor who’s a person of color who is willing to talk about discrimination in the workplace.

THERAPIST: I imagine it would be helpful to have a mentor who also has some similar (inaudible at 00:21:06) views.

CLIENT: Yeah. Or not even similar, just—she doesn’t—I find her very hard to read. And I don’t know that—I’m sure she has personal and political views. I just have no idea what they are. Generally speaking, I’m just like, “I don’t know.”

THERAPIST: I mean, she seems pretty buttoned up at work.

CLIENT: She’s super buttoned (ph) up. She’s not great with small talk. She likes the little—she likes an agenda or a plan for your discussion.

THERAPIST: I think (inaudible at 00:22:06) her actually being engaged with you. I mean, she sounds interested. And like she wants to help. But I don’t know how she responded to some of the stuff that you were describing, about Chet and whomever else. I mean, it sounds like she wasn’t taking in all that well where you were coming from. And was –

CLIENT: Yeah.

THERAPIST: patronizing, in various ways, across the things she said and suggested. It doesn’t sound like mal-intent, but certainly, for not having a sense of you.

CLIENT: Yeah. She flat out did not respond to anything I said to Will (inaudible at 00:23:07). Just has never responded.

THERAPIST: Mm-hmm. Does she know him?

CLIENT: Yeah. He works there.

THERAPIST: He’s at the business school, now, right?

CLIENT: Yeah. He works there. So, she knows him. We actually (inaudible at 00:23:20) over having lunch. (inaudible at 00:23:24) I feel a little—very awkward for us. Like, “Heh. I hate you.” The pleasant, “I hate you,” “I hate you, too. How are you doing?”

So, that happened. But yeah. And with Chet, I mean, I think she definitely feels like there’s something that I’m not doing. There’s something I’m doing wrong. Or something. She did say she—I think that she found it perplexing or confounding. I was like, “Yes.”

THERAPIST: “Now you’re starting to get it.”

CLIENT: “That is how I feel, as well.” And she also wasn’t aware of the lack of support that I get. I mean, I thought I told her, but she was surprised to hear that I probably—I needed to take a personal day or vacation day to attend this professional conference, because I’m not a professional employee. She didn’t know they didn’t have professional development funds. And a bunch of other things. It was like, “Yeah. I’m not a librarian, actually. I’m not a professional employee.”

I don’t know. To me, it didn’t seem like rocket science. I’m like, “I’m not a librarian. Why would I have access to stuff librarians get?” I’m like, “Well, I agree. It makes sense that I’m an invited speaker at a conference that I could go to the damn conference. Practically, I don’t think it’s—I don’t know that it’s going to happen.”

(inaudible at 00:25:30) preparing for the talk. That’s something that we’re going to briefly bring up, which is some people don’t get (inaudible at 00:25:40). (chuckles)

THERAPIST: Mm-hmm. Which (inaudible at 00:25:43) for your talk—(inaudible at 00:25:44) your talk.

CLIENT: The topic (sighs) is (inaudible at 00:25:46) speaking about whole libarianship, which is bringing your whole self to libarianship. And taking things that you’ve learned from other parts of your life into your work. Or asking work to consider things you do that aren’t technically librarian-y to be considered as professional development.

So, three (chuckles) of us are discussion queer activism, ‘zine making, other kinds of—working with LGBT, homeless youth, that’s three (chuckles) of us. And the other two are so—are—their non-traditional things are a little more traditional, I guess. I can’t remember. I think one of them—one person’s talking about some kind of (inaudible at 00:26:52) she volunteers with some people, like a youth group, like (inaudible at 00:26:58). Not a gay youth group. Just a youth group. Just (inaudible at 00:27:02). And someone else. I can’t remember what she does, either.

But it was things where I’m (sighs) the concept is applicable to everyone. I do think that you’re—the person who does—works with a youth group still has the skills of working with youth. Or maybe overhead meanings. Or both. Blah, blah, blah. It’s just that it’s going to be different. She has a different experience of working with youth than—if—like when I chaperone gay prom. It’s a little different. And then, if she chaperoned her school prom. It’d be a lot different.

And also, by my saying, “I chaperone gay prom,” I get—I am outing myself, which is fine, for me. But also, it brings up, like you said, I’m less likely to consider it a (inaudible at 00:28:13) skill because it’s all gay.

THERAPIST: Right. [There’s gayness on it] (ph).

CLIENT: Yeah. And also, some of the stuff, I’m just like, “I would like to discuss the mass amount of organizing I’ve done with (inaudible at 00:28:25), but I really hope that discussing a (inaudible at 00:28:27) group right now.” (chuckles)

And it’s really hard to—you—it’s hard to explain some of the—there just ends up being cultural context is where I’m like, “I don’t think that most people know how annoying it is to organize lesbians.” Because everyone knows the—how you should be talking, (inaudible at 00:29:02) whatever. So, passive-aggression can reach –

THERAPIST: (laughs)

CLIENT: astounding levels. Really astounding. And things we worry about include it’s really important that we can find one meal option is vegan. And –

THERAPIST: (chuckles)

CLIENT: another one is gluten free. And another one is this. And it’s just like, “Ugh.”

THERAPIST: (crosstalk at 00:29:29)

CLIENT: “I hate you all.” But then again, I’m doing that. I feel like I can organize anyone. I don’t care. But that, it’s hard to explain.

I guess, as I mentioned, I’m at this point where I’m like, “You’re a nice person, but” –

THERAPIST: Well, you’re describing her as being useless (inaudible at 00:29:57) counter-productive. I think.

CLIENT: Yeah. I don’t feel like I’ve –

THERAPIST: As a mentor, I should say. (crosstalk at 00:30:05) –

CLIENT: Yeah.

THERAPIST: not necessarily like as somebody to chat with a little bit. But as someone who—I mean, you (inaudible at 00:30:14) have not mentioned anything of value she’s said to you regarding the sorts of things you wanted a mentor for help with, I think.

CLIENT: Yes. And she doesn’t really understand what I—my job is. Which is a problem. When she saw (inaudible at 00:30:43), like, “Oh, I have to introduce you to someone who does blah, blah, blah.” I’m like, “Yeah. I already do that. That’s my job.” Or it’s like, “Yeah. That’s someone I can reach out to by virtue of”—she’s—I feel like I’m not getting introductions that are really—(inaudible at 00:31:12) useful to me. That’s a nice thing, that, but I don’t really want to talk to someone about [an implementation] (ph) of a mediascape table when I already did that. I’m like, A), I hate it, and B), I actually set that up. (chuckles) “And the person that I—that you want me to talk to is someone who didn’t.” I don’t know. Talking to a librarian who has used it is not that interesting to me, because—I don’t know.

THERAPIST: Yeah. I would think probably you have a bottom ten list of things you want to—work topics you wanted to talk more with people about. I would have to imagine media:scape tables would be on there somewhere.

CLIENT: Oh, yeah. Yeah. And, I mean, as it turns out, I think one of my friends’ business (inaudible at 00:32:13) school is probably someone who I would be better off talking about technology. If I wanted to. [Which I] (ph) don’t actually want to, but –

THERAPIST: So, I would imagine you’re annoyed by this whole mentor thing.

CLIENT: I am.

THERAPIST: I mean, it’s been a real disappointment.

CLIENT: Yeah.

THERAPIST: And frustrating.

CLIENT: (sighs) We’re doing (inaudible at 00:32:42) tomorrow morning. We’re doing a twoor three-hour shebang. It’s not end-of-program thing, I don’t think. If it’s not end-of-program, (inaudible at 00:32:56) it’s one step away from it. All I actually want to talk about to the program people is based on the sexism in the workplace. And I don’t know if I feel capable of doing that. Or capable of dealing with reactions to that. And I don’t want to bring it up (inaudible at 00:33:43) I don’t (inaudible at 00:33:45) feel comfortable bringing it up with my—the mentee group as a whole, because A), it’s mostly white people, B), I just sense a lot of defensiveness already from interactions and (inaudible at 00:34:01). I don’t know if (inaudible at 00:34:04) anyone else is—wants to talk about.

So, I’m just really—I feel like I’m finishing a program so I can say, “Look. I tried hard and finished this program.” Not because it’s getting me anywhere.

(pause)

CLIENT: And, for me, part of why, like I said, I just need to leave Manchester is—I just—I really feel like I would have to completely leave the Manchester library system to be able to do anything. And maybe I’d be better off using whatever Harvard prestige, wink, wink, wink, somewhere else. I don’t know. Cal Tech, Leslie (sp?), wherever.

And I’ve been wanting to stick it out. To finish the degree. And to not change jobs for moving cross-country. And now, I’m just like, “Or maybe I should do that.”

THERAPIST: The change jobs part, you mean?

CLIENT: Yeah.

THERAPIST: Uh-huh. When are you anticipating moving?

CLIENT: I don’t really have any timeline (inaudible at 00:35:55)—I finish my degree in December. And then, I anticipate wanting to face plant for a while. And then, start looking.

THERAPIST: At least a year.

CLIENT: At least a year. Yeah. And I also (inaudible at 00:36:16) I don’t know how long that job search would (ph) take. Or any (inaudible at 00:36:23). But realistically, I (inaudible at 00:36:25) for a year. And ideally, I would be feeling a little more emotionally stable. (chuckles) I would hope.

THERAPIST: Sure. And I don’t have an answer. (inaudible at 00:36:42) other part [of what’s tricky] (ph) is that (inaudible at 00:36:48) work is one of the things that has been very difficult emotionally –

CLIENT: Yeah.

THERAPIST: to deal with.

CLIENT: Yes. I don’t know. I mean, yeah, work is that thing that—I’m not feeling great for a variety of reasons. But the things that set me off and crying or feeling super defeated have all been—not all of—mostly been work stuff. So, there’s that. I’m not sure that I can find a way to have Paul not be my manager. Or to work in different space. Or a bazillion things.

The things that would make work much more tolerable to me I don’t think I can get, mostly because that they, “Well, it would look bad. What would people think if you changed desks?” Or changed managers.

THERAPIST: I don’t recall, in any conversation I can remember you telling me about, in which you brought something up that mattered to you to somebody at work. Or asked for something that mattered to you at work. That you got what you wanted. But moreover, felt like you were particularly well understood.

CLIENT: Yeah.

THERAPIST: Haven’t brought it up in the first place. At all. I mean, I’m just—I’m seconding what you’re saying, I guess.

CLIENT: Yeah.

THERAPIST: But I’m sure—I—maybe I—I can imagine I might hear a—there may have been some conversations that didn’t go as badly as most of the ones I’ve heard about. But, understandably, you didn’t tell me about those, because –

CLIENT: Right.

THERAPIST: we talk about things that (inaudible at 00:39:56). But yeah.

CLIENT: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. And I’m (inaudible at 00:40:15) like, “Do I try up the chain again? Is that going to go nowhere? Probably. Should I try”—thinking about—try and think of other ways to (sighs) I don’t know. I feel like half—I’m just being—I’m being defeatist. Maybe there is a way I could talk to someone. And they would actually listen. But then, I think, “No. I’m pretty sure that that’s not going to happen. But hmm.”

THERAPIST: Yeah. I don’t think you’re being defeatist. Nor do I think that it’s how you’re talking to people that’s the problem. I do wonder why you’re doubting yourself in those ways. Having (inaudible at 00:41:23) within so many conversations that have not gone that way. Do you know what I mean? It seems like more of—much more of a no-brainer to me than to you. (inaudible at 00:41:42) I have the sense that (inaudible at 00:41:47) has . . .

(pause)

THERAPIST: . . . you don’t want to feel like you’re being negative. Or (inaudible at 00:42:09) upsetting (inaudible at 00:42:09) has been. Something like that. I’m sure.

CLIENT: I think the other—one of the reasons why I doubt myself is—yeah. I don’t get a lot of affirmation when I talk to people about it. I get what I was getting from my mentor, like, “Oh, but that can’t be possible.” Or, “You should go fight that and talk to someone else.” And I’m like, “Cool story. Already tried that. I’m out of people to talk to.”

And I don’t know if people think—if (inaudible at 00:43:15) think they’re being encouraging or something. But (sighs) not a lot of people that I talk to about this will say, “That really sucks.” And, “You’ve tried a lot. And it sucks.” There’s much more, “Well, have you thought of doing this or this?” Or, “Surely, the problem is”—that I’m misunderstanding. Or that I’m being oversensitive. That I just don’t (inaudible at 00:44:00) worse or whatever.

THERAPIST: (inaudible at 00:44:07) with me.

CLIENT: Yeah.

THERAPIST: Right? (inaudible at 00:44:12)

CLIENT: (sighs)

THERAPIST: We should stop, for now.

CLIENT: Okay.

THERAPIST: (inaudible at 00:44:25) next week.

CLIENT: Yep.

END TRANSCRIPT
